titlestmt.titleproper: Richard E. Bishop papers, films, and paintings 1937-1981
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

did.unittitle: Richard E. Bishop papers, films, and paintings

bioghist.p: Richard Evett Bishop (1887-1975) was a painter, etcher, and photographer of wildlife subjects, particularly wildfowl. He graduated from Cornell University in 1909 with an M.E. degree and went to work as an electrical engineer for the Cutler-Hammer Manufacturing Company in Milwaukee. In 1915 he married Mary Ellen Harrington. The couple moved to Philadelphia, where Bishop worked at a manufacturing plant as a sales manager until his retirement from business in 1933. A number of his etchings and prints are in the collection of the National Gallery of Art in Washington D.C. He lived in Philadelphia and was a member of the Philadelphia Print Club and the Philadelphia Watercolor Society. In 1936, he published Bishop's Birds: Etchings of Water-fowl and Upland Game Birds. In the same year, J.N. "Ding" Darling, the Chief of the U.S. Biological Survey, asked Bishop if his drypoint of Canada geese, entitled "Coming In," could be used on the third Federal Duck Stamp.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of samples of the artwork of Richard Bishop and materials related to his artwork. Included are two framed oil paintings of the Mara River in Kenya, a sheet of pencil sketches of ducks in flight, and a bound souvenir volume related to the U.S. Department of Agriculture "Duck Stamp" designed by Bishop. The volume includes plates of Bishop's stamp, a series of humorous duck stamp drawings signed by friends, and a letter and several telegrams congratulating Bishop on the selection of his design. Included in the collection, but not bound into the volume are a U.S. Department of Agriculture brochure on the history of the duck stamp, and a press release announcing the selection of the winner of the 1982-1983 duck stamp competition. The collection also includes two 16 mm color films of birds, one entitled Prairie Wings.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
